Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Development of Urban Structure and Government

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Adrian Chase, of Arizona State University, will undertake research to study the urban form created and used by the ancient Maya. Ancient Maya urbanism is characterized by large low-density cities covering up to two hundred square kilometers; some had populations of up to (and sometimes over) 100,000 people; all had a reliance on seasonal tropical rainfall for both agriculture and subsistence. While Maya rulers, mostly known from texts recorded on stone monument, reigned over Classic Period (550 CE - 900 CE) Maya cities and states, court officials and support staff likely handled day-to-day administrative tasks within these cities. The ancient Maya provide an excellent case study to review the role that both top-down (elite) and bottom-up (household) processes can impact the day-to-day governance of ancient cities. This research incorporates excavation at the Maya city of Caracol, Belize, one of the most well documented Maya cities, with data analyses to determine governance patterns. Maya cities, like Caracol, were designed to harvest rainfall for both sustenance and agriculture, but these aspects alone did not provide for the longevity of these ancient cities. Caracol itself also thrived for over one thousand years because of its social and political organization. Additional understanding of governance at Caracol will help elucidate how this city functioned, shed light on its longevity, and provide data appropriate for theoretical formulations and cross-cultural comparisons. Research at Caracol also involves cooperation between United States and Belizean citizens, as well as building and reinforcing positive international ties between both countries on a variety of levels that include hands-on undergraduate archaeological training.


In this study, Adrian Chase assesses the degree to which aspects of the physical layout of a city (including the location of infrastructure, standardization of residential features, and neighborhood identity) provide practical proxies for identifying governance with Caracol, Belize as the test site location. Three datasets are used: 1) the distribution of urban service facility features around the city as a proxy for the degree of infrastructural power; 2) the degree of standardization of garden city features as a proxy for residential autonomy; and, 3) the patterning and distribution of ritual artifacts and their correlation with proposed neighborhoods as a proxy for the potential for collective action through neighborhood level identity. Through this research, concepts from more general urban theory in a variety of disciplines will be integrated with archaeological research through the operationalization of infrastructural power, household autonomy, and collective action at multiple scales of analysis: citywide, district, neighborhood, and plazuela household. Analysis of the built environment and archaeological material will augment the hieroglyphic narrative and provide a better understanding of the governance of a Late Classic Period Maya city.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many ancient Maya cities, including Caracol, existed as low-density cities that fully intermixed agriculture into the urban fabric of the city itself instead of maintaining a strict urban-rural dichotomy. In the case of Caracol, most of the city is comprised of plazuela residential groups that housed extended families, residential reservoirs that stored potable rainwater for domestic use, and agricultural terraces that provided essential agricultural goods. Clusters of plazuelas in residential neighborhoods likely coordinated to construct and maintain terraces given the downhill flow of terraced field to terraced field in the hilly environment of Caracol. The causeway road system connected a distributed network of market and administrative centers along its length providing the urban infrastructural backbone to hold this city together in a system of ?districts? which primarily provided urban services focused around formal plazas providing formal marketplaces and meeting space, ballcourts for the Mesoamerican ballgame, and e-groups for various other community functions.

 

This research has provided a better understanding of the intermediate levels of urban administration through neighborhoods and districts to augment our understanding of plazuela residential groups and analysis of the city as a whole. Excavation data from 2019 and prior field seasons of excavation have highlighted distinctive neighborhoods based on small differences in household caching and burial practices. Computer analysis of lidar data has allowed for the identification additional market and administrative nodes, and shown which specific urban service facility features are present among district nodes including formal plazas, ballcourts, and e-groups. Together this dataset helps shed light on how the people of Caracol governed their ancient city through three aspects. First, the degree of centralization for the district level urban services presents a strict hierarchical scale where every node with an e-group has a ballcourt and every node with a ballcourt has a formal plaza, but the inverse of these statements does not hold. Additionally, the ancient Maya constructed these features in a distributed fashion indicating wider accessibility of features than if they had been clustered into the downtown. Second, the individual households maintained a relatively high degree of autonomy from direct administration based on the wide variation present in area and volume, but still maintained a specific distances from each other to provide ample agricultural land in many cases. Finally, reconstructed neighborhoods, based on a sample of four - with two near the downtown and two near other market nodes - show similarities in ritual material culture within each neighborhood but differences between neighborhoods indicating the potential collective action based on similarities in identity at the neighborhood level. However, overall similarities also highlight the importance of a shared market access and distribution leading to overall similarities that could constitute a ?Caracol identity? ? especially since not all Maya cities show such similarities in household material among both the wealthier and poorer residents.

 

The city of Caracol thrived for over 1000 years in what would today be considered a ?marginal? jungle environment relying on harvesting rainfall for both sustenance and agriculture. While the governance, technology, and culture of ancient Caracol differ from those of cities today, aspects of these ancient cities can provide inspiration for modern sustainable practices even if we cannot directly export ancient practices into modern contexts. However, the nature of governance is necessary to understand how ancient administration worked and has implications about ancient sustainability.
